moves.1. e4 Nf6: I have never played against the Alekhine Defence before, so I'm not very experienced at it.
moves.2... Nd5 3. d4: I'm trying to control the centre and gain tempo by kicking the knight.
moves.3... e6 4. Bc4 d6: Attempting to undermine my centre control.
moves.5. Nf3: Developing and attacking the centre, while allowing me to castle.
moves.5... Nc6: Contesting the control of the knight on f3.
moves.6. O-O: I castle and hide my king away.
moves.6... Be7: Preparing to castle. Black is not in a very enviable position (at least for me), because his pieces are in a closed position.
moves.7. Bxd5: Probably a bad idea, because it allows exd5, which opens up the diagonal for the LSB.
moves.7... exd5 8. Nc3: Developing and applying pressure to the d5-pawn.
moves.8... dxe5: Trading and opening up the position.
moves.9. dxe5 Be6: Defending the d-pawn and developing his final minor piece.
moves.10. Be3: I also develop my final piece.
moves.10... O-O: Now that there are no more immediate threats, black castles.
moves.12. a3: I want the bishop out of my territory.
moves.12... Bxc3 13. bxc3: I made a visual error here, thinking that the f6-knight wasn't there, so I played this instead of Qxc6, because I thought that d4 was a serious fork.
moves.13... Na5: Preparing for Nc4, which allows black to exchange his knight for my bishop with tempo.
moves.15... Nc4: Black won't gain a free pawn (a6) because of Rxb7.
moves.16. Qd3: Attacking the knight while keeping h7 in sight.
moves.17. Rxb7 Bf5: Skewering the queen to the c2-pawn.
moves.18... Nc4: ? This gives away the chance to break even in pawns. Better would be Nxc2.
moves.19. Rxa7 Rxa7 20. Qxa7: I am now ahead by a pawn.
moves.20... f6: Threatening the bishop, though this seems a bit risky.
moves.21... gxf6 22. Bh6: I threaten the rook, while getting in a good position to limit the king's movements.
moves.22... Rf7: Blocking off the flight square of f7.
moves.23. Qa8+: I throw in a check with a mating threat. Only one move allows black to escape...
moves.23... Qc8: And black finds it. At least I can gain a pawn.
moves.24. Qxd5 Nd6: Black moves his knight to a protected position.
moves.25. Bf4: I attack the knight. For the next few moves, my queen does not get a single breath in as it is threatened by multiple pieces and a pawn.
moves.33. Rd1: I apply pressure to the LSB.
moves.33... Bxf3 34. gxf3: The exchange has given my king an open file, as well as one for black's rook.
moves.36. Qe4: If the black queen moves wrongly, Qe8#.
moves.37. Ke2: Escaping while helping to defend f3.
moves.37... Rf7: Qe8+ is no longer mate, thanks to this move.
moves.38. Qxc6: I grab a pawn in the meantime.
moves.38... Re7+ 39. Be3: I decide to block the check this time, as I have no intention of being chased around the board.
moves.39... Re6: Kicking the queen. I can now chase the king around.
moves.40. Qc8+: Check, as well as pinning the rook to the queen.
moves.40... Kg7 41. Rd7+: I bring my rook into play, hoping to get a forced mate.
moves.41... Kg6: The only move. Re7 only postpones this move.
moves.42. Qg8+ Kf5 43. Qxh7+: I grab a pawn with check.
moves.44. Qe4#: Checkmate! I hope you enjoyed this annotation, and you're welcome to post constructive feedback. Good game f00fighter.
